68.155(d) Five-Year Accident History
There is no accident history to report.

68.155(e) Emergency Response Plan
OXARC, Inc. has an Emergency Action Plan in lieu of an Emergency Response Plan due to the few employees on-site during operations. The plan includes all required aspects of the Action Plan and was created using OSHA's Emergency Action Plan Expert System. The plan identifies alerts, what to do in the event of an emergency, evacuation, extinguishers, operations, employee duties, and meeting points and accountability.

Franklin County LEPC is the Local Emergency Planning Committee covering this facility.

68.155(f) Planned Changes to Improve Safety
OXARC, Inc. has no plans at the present time.

equipment associated with the process.

Management of Change. The most recent review/revision of procedures was performed on 3/28/2022. Employees whose job tasks are affected by a modification in the operating procedures are promptly made aware of and trained in these changes. 

Compliance Audits. The most recent Compliance Audit was completed at the facility on 01/31/2020. The Compliance Audit identified several opportunities for improvement, which were completed by 03/13/2020.

Incident Investigation. OXARC, Inc. promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could result in an unintentional release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years. There has not been an incident at this facility.

Employee Participation. OXARC, Inc. believes that safety management and accident prevention is a team effort. OXARC employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. OXARC employees are given the opportunity to voice any concerns during monthly safety meetings as well as through an open-door policy. In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of this facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from any hazard analyses.

Contractors. On occasion, OXARC, Inc. hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety of the contractor is carried out. OXARC has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractors work and the processes. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release occur. However, contractors are not involved with any process r

anufactured from the mixing calcium carbide and water in a generator. The chemical reaction produces acetylene gas which is purified and compressed prior to bottling.  

68.155(c) General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
This facility has taken all of the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth in 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at this facility.

Process Safety Information. OXARC, Inc. maintains safety information that describes the chemical hazards, handling, and storage of the regulated substance at this facility. All affected personnel are trained on hazmat handling.

Process Hazard Analysis. This facility conducts reviews to ensure that hazards associated with the handling, storage, manufacturing, and filling of cylinders are identified and controlled efficiently. Any findings related the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner. The most recent PHA review was performed on 11/01/2019.

Operating Procedures. For the purpose of safely handling, filling, and storing cylinders, OXARC, Inc. has written procedures that address the loading, unloading, and safe handling of cylinders. Oxarc follows guidance set forth by the Compressed Gas Association (CGA) as well as the Acetylene Plant Owner's Manual in determining the safe operating conditions and required inspections and tests necessary to maintain the acetylene manufacturing operations.

Training. OXARC, Inc. has a comprehensive program in place to ensure employees who are responsible for the handling of hazardous substances are competent in the procedures. Refresher training is provided on an ongoing basis.

Executive Summary 

OXARC, Inc.
500 S. Main Ave.
Pasco, WA 99301

PROCESSES: 1000124350 - Cylinder Storage
           1000124351 - Acetylene Manufacturing

68.155(a) Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
OXARC, Inc. is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the company's comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as receipt of containers and product, storage, and employee training associated with the chemicals at this facility. It is policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. 

Under the Accidental Release Prevention Program, responsibility for the proper handling and storage of toxic gases stored at the OXARC - Pasco, Washington facility is overseen by the EHS Manager and by the EHS Coordinator. Additionally, OXARC, Inc. senior management have responsibility to ensure facility managers and compliance personnel keep the program up-to-date and that all reports and findings are taken care of in a timely manner.

68.155(b) The Regulated Substances Handled
The facility is accessible to about eighty-four (84) authorized employees and is secured during non-operational hours.  There are three (3) substances at this facility above the threshold quantity. 

Sulfur dioxide and chlorine (separate, not in mixtures) are stored and handled at the facility in compressed gas cylinders. The estimated maximum amount of sulfur dioxide on hand is approximately 55,000 pounds total in 1,200-pound and 150-pound containers. The maximum amount of chlorine on hand is approximately 78,000 pounds in 2,000-pound and 150-pound containers. There are no filling processes performed for either of these chemicals at this facility.
